ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Effect of Gd3+ doping on structural, optical and frequency-dependent dielectric response properties of pseudo-cubic BaTiO3 nanostructures

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Nanoscience and Soft Matter Laboratory, Department of Physics
School of Engineering and Applied Sciences

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
We report on the structural, optical and dielectric characterization of solid state derived, pseudo-cubic nanoscale barium titanates (BTs) with gadolinium (Gd3+) as substitutional dopant. Referring to X-ray diffractograms, apart from the BT peaks related to perovskite structure, the non-existence of any additional peaks due to byproducts has revealed that Gd3+ has undergone substitutional doping into the BT host lattice. The well-separated BT nanoparticles of typical size ∼10–15 nm were observed through electron microscopy studies. Following a direct, allowed type carrier transition (n=1/2), a reduction in the optical band gap value (from 3.28 to 3.255 eV) was observed when the Gd-doping level was varied within 0–7 %. Conversely, the Urbach energy followed an increasing trend, from a value of 0.741 to 1.879 eV. Furthermore, the dielectric constant showed a decreasing tendency with doping content and with increasing frequency. However, in the low-frequency region, the loss tangent (tanδ), which is the combined result of orientational polarization and electrical conduction, was found to be quite high in the doped samples as compared to their un-doped counterpart. The frequency-dependent electrical data were also analyzed in the framework of conductivity and impedance formalisms. In particular, the ac conductivity which varies as ∼ω
s approaches ideal Debye behavior (s→1) for a low Gd level and a higher doping concentration did not show improved dielectric feature of the host. The incorporation of rare-earth (Gd3+) ions into the BT host system could greatly manifest dielectric relaxation and carrier conduction mechanisms, in a given frequency range, and thus can find immense scope in miniaturized nanoelectronic elements including ceramic capacitors and transducers.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In recent years, among various perovskite nanomaterials, barium titanate (BaTiO3, BT) has received significant attention due to the exhibition of interesting optoelectronic properties such as photoluminescence and electroluminescence responses [1, 2] along with much emphasized dielectric, piezoelectric and ferroelectric characteristics [3–5]. In addition to non-hazardous and environmentally friendly nature, unique physical properties of BT make it suitable for potential application in transducers, actuators, random access memories and other integrated optoelectronic components with much greater reliability and superior performance [3–6]. BT is the most conventional displacive-type ferroelectric system which exhibits spontaneous polarization at room temperature. Out of its five known crystal structures, displayed in independent temperature ranges, the most important ferroelectric (tetragonal) phase gets converted to paraelectric (cubic) phase at the Curie temperature (T c∼120 ∘C). Due to its high technological and industrial demand, in the past, a vast deal of research effort was put into considering both theoretical and experimental aspects. With the realization of sophisticated processing tools and conceptually advanced fabrication routes, nanoscale BT layers could be accurately developed using epitaxial techniques [7]. Conversely, an assortment of ways such as controlled solid state process [8], sol–gel route [9], hydrothermal method [10] etc. have also been adopted to obtain quality nanopowders. As one has to sacrifice the tetragonality feature at the cost of size reduction, it is still challenging to retain ferroelectric response of much smaller crystallites [11].

In the cubic phase of a perovskite (ABO3) system, the oxygen atoms form a cubic lattice of corner-sharing octahedra with the B cations at their centers, while the A cations form a second interpenetrating cubic sub-lattice located at the 12-fold-coordinated sites between the octahedra. Interestingly, most of the perovskite compounds that are of great technological interest are not simple systems, but rather complex oxides with two different kinds of B atoms of the form A(B′B″)O3. Investigation with respect to the electrical properties of these materials is highly desirable to assess their suitability for different applications. It is known that an appropriate amount of doping into the BT host can improve structural, optical and electrical properties of the system significantly [12–15]. Complex perovskite oxides with high dielectric constants play an important role in various technological applications, for instance in wireless communication systems, microelectronics and global positioning systems. High dielectric constant allows one to fabricate smaller capacitive components, thus offering an opportunity to shrink the size of the electronic devices [16]. Various relaxation processes seem to coexist in complex perovskite ceramics, which are accompanied by a number of different energy barriers associated with the point defects developed during the fabrication process. Therefore, in ceramic systems, a departure from the ideal Debye model, resulting from the interaction of dipoles, cannot be disregarded [17].

As far as doping is concerned, various physical properties of the BT systems such as crystal anisotropy, dielectric and piezoelectric responses etc. can be substantially modified by varying the concentrations of dopants and additives. Much emphasis was given earlier to dope with transition metals [12], alkaline earth metals [13] and to the lanthanide group of rare-earth (RE) ions [14, 15]. The RE ions have unfilled, interlocked 4f-electronic structure, which could help inducing numerous exciting features related to radiative emission, up-conversion and magnetism. The RE-doping-led improved dielectric, electro-optic, luminescence and nonlinear optical responses have already been witnessed by earlier workers [18, 19]. As a classic lanthanide element, Gd exhibits unusual metallurgical properties, apart from its significant use in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The inclusion of Gd into the pseudo-cubic host lattice of BT is rarely found in the literature, and, in this report, we demonstrate the influence of gadolinium (Gd3+) doping on the structural, band tailing and dielectric properties of such nanostructures. The effect of doping on the lattice parameter, tetragonality, band profile and frequency-dependent dielectric permittivity and impedance profile are discussed in the light of an appropriate theoretical model.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: The solid state mixing cum decomposition reaction process and analytical tools used in the present study are as detailed below.

Section2.Heading: Synthesis of nanoscale BT with gadolinium as dopant
Section2.Para:
For synthesis, a simple, cost-effective and straightforward approach was considered following a recent report [20]. In a typical solid-state process, at first, equal moles of BaCO3 (Merck, 99.99 %) and TiO2 (Merck, 99.99 %) were transferred to a thoroughly cleaned agate mortar followed by soft and unidirectional grinding for about 2 h. The uniformly ground sample was then transferred to a silica crucible followed by calcination in a muffle furnace (at 1000 °C) for 4 h. The specimen was subjected to further grinding in a closed chamber, at least for 1/2 h. Essentially, the solid-state reaction facilitates spontaneous decomposition of BaCO3 to BaO (driving off CO2) and a subsequent reaction with TiO2 could result in the desired BT product. In order to fabricate Gd-doped BT systems, gadolinium acetate [Gd(O2C2H3)3⋅xH2O, GdAc] was introduced along with the other reactants during the initial step of the solid-state process. We have considered four doping concentrations, with Gd-to-Ti molar ratios as 0.01, 0.03, 0.07 and 0.1. The rest of the steps, in the fabrication procedure, remained the same as the case for the un-doped one. It is worth mentioning here that Gd was not incorporated into the pure-BT product but Gd-doped BT nanostructured systems were obtained by following the complete solid-state reaction, with GdAc added as a reactant in the initial step itself. All the nanoscale BT products were collected in the form of powder and kept ready for subsequent experimentation. The chemical reactions involved can be expressed as
$$\begin{aligned} &\mathrm{BaCO}_{3}~(\mathrm{s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{BaO}\ (\mathrm{s}) + \mathrm{CO}_{2}~(\mathrm{g}), \\ &\mathrm{BaO} + \mathrm{TiO}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{BaTiO}_{3}. \end{aligned}$$ Note that, due to thermal treatment, GdAc would lead to the formation of intermediate oxycarbonates [(GdO)2CO3] with H2O and CO2 as primary gaseous products. The subsequent heating of the (GdO)2CO3 phase could result in the final decomposition and, consequently, formation of Gd2O3 and a gaseous product like CO2. In the doping process, the Gd3+ ions get incorporated into the Ti4+ sites [21], creating thereby a number of positive oxygen vacancy sites in the lattice. The possible incorporation reaction of trivalent Gd3+ which also leads to creation of positive oxygen vacancy sites can be written using notation proposed by Kröger and Vink [22]:
$$2 \mathrm{BaO}+ \mathrm{Gd}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \leftrightarrow 2\mathrm{Ba}_{\mathrm{Ba}} +4 \mathrm{Gd}_{\mathrm{Ti}} ' + 5\mathrm{O}_{\mathrm{o}} + 5O_{\mathrm{o}}^{^{..}} $$ A similar way of representing the formation of oxygen vacancies, due to inclusion of divalent and trivalent alkaline dopants in the BT system, has also been reported elsewhere [23].

Section2.Heading: Characterization tools and techniques
Section2.Para: The crystallographic as well as microstructural characteristics of the as-prepared un-doped and Gd3+-doped BT nanosystems were explored by X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies, recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer employing Cu-K α radiation (λ=1.543 Å), whereas morphological aspects were investigated by a high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100). The optical absorption studies were performed by using a UV–visible absorption spectrophotometer (UV 2450, Shimadzu Corporation). For measuring dielectric permittivity and ac conductivity of BT nanostructures, standard pellets (1.5 mm thick, 10.6 mm diameter) were prepared with the help of a hydraulic press by applying a pressure of 68.9 MPa. The values of impedance, capacitance and loss tangents of the pellets were recorded using a Hioki 3532-50 LCR Hi-Tester, operating in the frequency range 100 Hz to 5 MHz. A typical sample holder comprising stainless steel blocking electrodes was used to hold the pellets. The probe lids were interfaced to the device and, consequently, to a PC for data acquisition/analysis. The input parameters were varied through fully computer controlled software procured with the LCR meter. All measurements were carried out in the ambient environment and at room temperature (298 K).

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para: In order to exploit crystallographic, structural, optical and dielectric relaxation properties, the as-synthesized gadolinium-doped BT nanostructures were characterized independently by different tools. The results are presented in different sub-sections as below.

Section2.Heading: Structural and morphological analysis of Gd3+-doped nanoscale BT systems
Section2.Para: X-ray diffraction was used to reveal crystallographic features of as-synthesized nano-BT powder, whereas electron microscopy imaging was employed to exploit morphological details of the nanoscale product.

Section3.Heading: Crystal lattice structure, crystallite size and tetragonality
Section3.Para:
The XRD patterns of the nano-BT systems, measured in the range of Bragg’s diffraction angle of 20–70°, are depicted in Fig. 1a. Typically, the diffractograms characterize perovskite crystal structure of BT. Though there is a shifting of the (110) peak toward a lower Bragg angle with doping, no additional peaks corresponding to any byproducts or other intermediate products such as BaO were observed in the XRD patterns. With a preferred orientation along the (110) plane (located at 31°, for un-doped BT), the other peaks could be readily indexed to planes (100), (111), (200), (210), (211) and (220) of the perovskite system which were located at respective angles of 22.2°, 39°, 45.29°, 50.95°, 56.26° and 65.9°.
Fig. 1
(a) XRD patterns of un-doped and Gd3+-doped nano-BT systems, (b) typical shifting of peak position with Gd doping

The average crystallite size (D) and microstrain (η) can be obtained from the popular Williamson–Hall expression given by
1
$$ \beta \cos \theta = 4\eta \sin \theta + \frac{0.9\lambda}{D}. $$ Here, β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) corresponding to the diffraction peak. It is also possible to evaluate the lattice parameters (a=b and c) and tetragonality (c/a) of the un-doped and Gd3+-doped nano-BT systems. For a tetragonal structure, with (hkl) as Miller indices and a (=b) and c as lattice parameters,
2
$$ \frac{1}{d^{2}} = \frac{h^{2} + k^{2}}{a^{2}} + \frac{l^{2}}{c^{2}}, $$ where d is the separation between successive atomic planes (inter-planar spacing). Knowing that the c/a ratio is a measure of tetragonal symmetry, most lead and barium titanates, with large enough crystallite sizes, experience a value ∼1.06 [24]. As a result of particle size reduction, the c/a value decreases and becomes close to unity below the critical size. The system is then no more in tetragonal phase but possesses a cubic symmetry. It is also useful to make an assessment of nanoscale defect density. Generally, a dislocation is a crystallographic deformity, defect or irregularity within a crystal structure. The dislocation density formula is given by
3
$$ \delta_{\mathrm{d}} = \biggl( \frac{5\eta}{D} \biggr) \biggl( \frac{h}{a} + \frac{k}{b} + \frac{l}{c} \biggr), $$ where η is the microstrain and can be calculated for a single XRD peak as η=βcosθ/4. Thus, if we consider the (100) peak (where k=l=0), the magnitude of the dislocation density can be evaluated from the reduced form of Eq. (3), given by [25]
4
$$ \delta_{\mathrm{d}} = \frac{15 \beta \cos \theta}{4 a D}. $$ The presence of dislocations would strongly influence a number of physical properties. The associated mechanism of formation could be inhomogeneous nucleation, grain-boundary initiation, surface–interface properties, precipitates, dispersed phases etc. An abrupt phase separation during the nucleation of crystallites would lead to a number of dislocations. With particle size reduction, the increase in dislocation density may also help increasing the mechanical strength of the system.

The diffractograms of nano-BT systems with a permissible amount of Gd3+ doping (up to 7 %) have shown similar characteristics to the un-doped case, and no secondary peak corresponding to Gd or its oxide byproducts was detected. However, when the doping concentration was increased to 10 %, along with the conventional peaks, three additional peaks were observed at Bragg angles of ∼28.2, 33.3 and 47° corresponding to free Gd2O3 phases (Fig. 1a). Earlier, the upper limit of substitutional Mn doping in the perovskite system was predicted in the range of 7–10 % [26]. We also predict that, in the case of Gd doping, the permissible limit of substitutional doping is below 10 %. Moreover, lack of the (200) peak splitting into its (200) and (002) components suggests that the studied systems do not possess a pure tetragonal phase. Nevertheless, a broadened (200) peak would represent the existence of a cubic crystalline overlayer with a tetragonal core. Earlier, Zhu et al. have showed the formation of a ∼3.5-nm-thick cubic layer surrounding the inner tetragonal core of the BT nanoparticles [27]. It was anticipated that, with the decrease in particle size, a significant growth of the cubic overlayer will occur at the expense of the tetragonal core, and the whole structure becomes a cubic one below a critical dimension. With an increased level of Gd content, an apparent shifting of the preferential peak was observed toward a lower angle (Fig. 1b). This could be ascribed to the incompatibility arisen due to a difference in ionic radii of Ti4+ (∼0.068 nm) and Gd3+ (∼0.094 nm) that make up the crystal lattice. The incompatibility was much realized along the preferential (110) growth plane of the crystallites, and with an increase in crystallite size and lattice parameters [28]. The observed trend of increase in tetragonality (c/a) and crystallite size (D) with doping can be found in Table 1 and Fig. 2. The microstrain also showed an increasing trend with increasing dopant concentration. The magnitudes associated with D, microstrain and c/a have increased from 8.05 nm to 9.15 nm, 0.00232 to 0.00336 and 1.0038 to 1.0088 for un-doped and 7 % Gd-doped BT systems, respectively. The increased crystallite dimension is apparently due to the expansion of the crystal unit cell where Gd3+ is accommodated into some of the Ti4+ sites as substitution into Ba2+ site is energetically unfavorable.
Fig. 2

The dislocation density of the investigated systems was also calculated using Eq. (3). The magnitudes of δ d for un-doped and 1, 3 and 7 % Gd-doped BT nanostructured systems were estimated to be 5.37×105, 7.26×105, 4.69×105 and 5.36×105/μm2, respectively. Consequently, one could predict an average number of dislocations present in each of the crystallites, i.e. 32.5, 47.3, 31.5 and 39.2. Although the dislocation density has not been manifested by several orders of magnitude, it has an influence on the doping concentration. Since the average crystallite size is extremely small, most of the atoms cover the surface of the nanocrystallites and, consequently, presence of line defects, e.g. linear (edge) dislocation types, was prevalent at large.

Section3.Heading: Nanoscale morphology and lattice fringes
Section3.Para:
The morphological assessment of the nano-BT systems was accomplished by HRTEM studies. As can be found in Fig. 3a, nanoparticles with an average size range of ∼10–15 nm were evident from the low-magnification micrograph. An isolated pseudo-cubic nanoparticle having edges and faces can be observable in the enlarged view of the micrograph (Fig. 3b). At a higher magnification, the crystal lattice fringes were clearly distinguishable with an inter-planar spacing of ∼0.25 nm corresponding to the (111) plane of the BT system (Fig. 3c). The selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) of the specimen, shown as a figure inset, is characterized by diffused diffraction rings along with scattered bright spots. It suggests that the sample is mainly polycrystalline in nature along with a low percentage of monocrystalline phase. The shape of the BT nanoparticles was manifested by an irregular pseudo-cubic shape upon Gd doping, as can be found in Fig. 3d. The average dimension varies in the range of ∼15–25 nm. A well-resolved lattice fringe pattern of the highly crystalline nanoparticle allows the accurate calculation of the inter-planar spacing (∼0.25 nm) similar to the case of the un-doped system (Fig. 3e). The SAED pattern shows distinct and aligned bright spots arising out of the characteristic diffraction feature along the (111) plane of the single-crystal system (inset of Fig. 3e). We also noticed cross-interfering fringes in a typical nanostructure, shown in Fig. 3f. The existence of multiple crystal fringes along different orientations is due to irregular stacking of crystallites that make up the nanoparticle. The point defects and dislocations are identified by red and blue arrows. Apart from these, an important feature of the Gd-doped BT nanostructured system is the presence of intra-grain boundaries owing to loosely packed atoms in the region separating different crystallites. Owing to Gd incorporation into the host BT, the crystallites have suffered uneven stacking and, consequently, experienced an irregular overall shape.
Fig. 3
(a) HRTEM micrograph of un-doped nano-BT system, (b) an enlarged view depicting pseudo-cubic morphology and (c) lattice fringe and SAED pattern as figure insets. The respective images for 3 % Gd-doped nano-BT systems are shown in (d)–(f). The collective view, single crystalline fringe view and cross-interfering fringes are highlighted in (d), (e) and (f), respectively

Section2.Heading: Effect of Gd3+ doping on optical characteristics
Section2.Para: UV–visible optical absorption spectroscopy of the as-synthesized BT nanopowders was carried out in the wavelength range of 250–600 nm for evaluating band gaps and band tailing aspects.

Section3.Heading: Optical band gap calculation
Section3.Para:
The doped and un-doped systems were characterized by a broad absorption peak at ∼327 nm. (Fig. 4a). A distinct red shift of the absorption band edge was also observed with doping, thus indicating a wider size distribution and larger particle size with increase in impurity (Gd3+) content. The shifting of the absorption edge toward higher-energy values, as a result of higher doping concentration, is referred to as the Burstein–Moss effect/shift, also known as band filling or phase-space filling [29, 30]. Here, the red shift in the absorption curves could be associated with the shrinkage of the band gap of BT nanosystems due to the introduction of additional energy levels within the band gap. The optical band gap of a system can be calculated by using Tauc’s relation. We can employ Tauc’s relation to reveal the effect of Gd3+ doping on the optical gaps of BT nanosystems [31]:
5
$$ \alpha h\nu = A \bigl(h \nu - E_{\mathrm{g}}^{\mathrm{opt}} \bigr)^{n}. $$ Here, hν is the incident photon energy, α is the absorption coefficient,
$E_{\mathrm{g}}^{\mathrm{opt}}$ is the optical band gap, A is a system-dependent parameter and n is a parameter that changes with the nature of the transition. For instance, n=1/2,2,3/2 and 3 for direct allowed transition, indirect allowed transition, direct forbidden transition and indirect forbidden transition. In the case of an allowed transition, carriers migrate vertically from the top of the valence band to the bottom of the conduction band via absorption of incident photons. When both the bands are vertically aligned along the Γ-valley, the transition of carriers does not involve any change in momenta. Conversely, in the case of an indirect band gap system, the top of the valence band and the bottom of the conduction band are not aligned along the Γ-valley and a carrier transition is accompanied by optical phonon momenta.
Fig. 4
UV–visible absorption spectra of (a) un-doped and Gd3+-doped nano-BT systems, (b) corresponding Tauc plots of (αhν)2 vs. hν for estimation of optical band gaps

The direct optical band gap can be estimated from Eq. (1) taking n=1/2, plotting the variation of (αhν)2 vs. hν and extrapolating the best linear fit toward the x-axis (Fig. 4b) [20]. The optical band gap (
$E_{\mathrm{g}}^{\mathrm{opt}}$ ) showed a decreasing trend with increase in doping concentration. The
$E_{\mathrm{g}}^{\mathrm{opt}}$ value has dropped from 3.282 eV for the un-doped BT system to 3.255 eV for the 7 % Gd-doped BT system (Fig. 4b). The reason behind the band narrowing could also be due to many-body effects of the free carriers, which lower the electron energies as compared to a non-interacting carrier system. These interactions may be in the form of electron–electron, electron–donor, hole–hole, hole–acceptor or electron–hole interactions [32]. The substitution of Ti4+ by Gd3+ and subsequent charge imbalance at the designated site could lead to the creation of a large number of charged point defects. The introduction of compositional disorder leading to such defects is due to the difference in charge, ionic radii and change in bond lengths between Ti–O and Gd–O, etc.

Section3.Heading: Urbach energy estimation
Section3.Para:
Unlike crystalline semiconductors, a polycrystalline and disordered system exhibits a tailing in the optical absorption spectra. In the tailing region of density of states, carrier absorption takes place between the extended states of the valence band and the empty tail states of the conduction band. An equally probable case could be transition of carriers from the occupied valence band edge states to the empty extended states of the conduction band. In the tailing region, the absorption coefficient of a system under consideration can vary with photon energy as per Urbach’s rule, given by [33]
6
$$\begin{aligned} &\alpha = B\exp \biggl[ \frac{h\nu}{E_{\mathrm{U}}} \biggr], \end{aligned}$$
7
$$\begin{aligned} &\ln \alpha = B + \frac{h\nu}{E_{\mathrm{U}}}. \end{aligned}$$ Here, the Urbach energy (E U) is associated with the width of the tail so as to represent localized states within the band gap. The parameter B is dependent on the system under consideration and need not be equal to A.

The Urbach energy can be calculated by plotting the logarithm of the absorption coefficient against photon energy and taking the inverse of the slope of the linear part of the graph (Fig. 5a). As can be observed, E U is found to increase from a nominal value of 0.741 eV for the un-doped BT system to enhanced values of 1.477, 1.591 and 1.879 eV for 1, 3 and 7 % Gd-doped BT systems, respectively (Fig. 5b). Therefore, optical gap energy has a decreasing tendency with the increase in doping concentration, whereas the Urbach energy followed an increasing trend. It may be noted that, as compared to the un-doped case, a significant variation was observed for a 1 % Gd-doped BT sample but the trend did not follow a steep rise/fall with increasing doping concentration (Fig. 5b). Thus, we can invoke two important arguments: first, distinct localized levels within the gap state were formed due to Gd doping but introduction of a higher concentration may lead to the creation of subsequent states, with an energy spacing tens of meV. Second, the Urbach energy, which is a measure of tailing width, is significantly improved owing to enhanced probability of carrier transitions via localized states. Note, however, that these localized states are purely Gd-based and are quite different from other intrinsic defects (point defects such as vacancies and antisites etc.) of the host BT system which might be present in its nanoscale form.
Fig. 5
(a) ln α vs. hν plot for the calculation of the Urbach energy (E U) of un-doped and Gd-doped nano-BT systems, (b) variation of the optical band gap and the Urbach energy with Gd doping

Section2.Heading: Characteristic dielectric response of Gd3+-doped BT nanosystems
Section2.Para: The dielectric spectroscopic data of the synthesized nano-BT systems were obtained by using an impedance analyzer operating in a given frequency range.

Section3.Heading: Dielectric relaxation and loss tangent
Section3.Para:
The dielectric features of a solid-state system generally correspond to its charge-holding capacity at a definite frequency. In this regard, BT is known to be a very good dielectric which finds promising use in ceramic capacitors [6]. A standard capacitive measurement technique can be used for obtaining the dielectric constant:
8
$$ \varepsilon' = Cd /\varepsilon_{0} \varDelta, $$ where C is the measured capacitance, d is the thickness (∼1.5 mm) of the nano-BT pellet, ε 0 is the permittivity (8.85×10−12 F/m) of free space and Δ is the area of the pellet (∼13 mm2).

As a general trend, the Gd-doped BT systems would experience a higher charge-accumulating capacity with respect to their un-doped counterpart. But, in the low-frequency range (100 to 1000 Hz), the capacitance drops substantially exhibiting a sharp fall, as can be found in Fig. 6. At a higher frequency, the charge carriers are able to follow an ac frequency and tend to be mobile thereby suppressing the capacitive response. The dielectric constant and loss tangent also experience a decreasing trend with increase in frequency, but to different extents (Fig. 7). This is the characteristic feature of all polar dielectrics irrespective of composition and desired stoichiometry. The fall in ε′ arises from the fact that polarization does not occur instantaneously with the application of the electric field, which is further due to the inertia of the dipoles and the delay in response toward the impressed alternating electric field, resulting in dielectric loss and fall-off feature of ε′. The effect of Gd doping on the real part (ε′) of the frequency-dependent dielectric permittivity of nano-BT systems is shown in Fig. 7a. A polar material generally exhibits multi-component polarizability characteristics: deformational (electronic and ionic) polarization and relaxation (orientational and interfacial) polarization. The electronic polarization (frequency ∼1016 Hz) arises due to the displacement of the valence electrons relative to positive nuclei, whereas ionic polarization (frequency ∼1013 Hz) occurs due to the displacement of negative and positive ions with respect to each other. Among the two components of the relaxation polarization type, dipolar polarization (frequency ∼1010 Hz) occurs if the system contains molecules with permanent electric dipole moment that can change the orientation in the direction of the applied electric field. The space-charge polarization occurs in the frequency range up to 103 Hz and is mostly due to the mobile charge carriers through interfaces. By and large, at low frequencies, all types of polarization, viz: electronic, ionic, orientational and space-charge polarization, contribute, but, as the applied frequency increases, polarization response with a larger relaxation time (except for electronic polarization) ceases and, as a result, the ε′ value is suppressed [34, 35]. This is because, although they follow the ac field at a very low frequency, they begin to lag behind the field with increase in frequency (relaxation process). A similar frequency-dependent dielectric behavior was also witnessed in other perovskite ceramic systems [36, 37].
Fig. 6
Frequency-dependent capacitance response of un-doped and Gd3+-doped BT nanostructures
Fig. 7
The frequency-dependent dielectric response of un-doped and Gd3+-doped nano-BT systems: (a) the real part of the permittivity and (b) the loss tangent (tan δ)

The loss tangent (tanδ) of a dielectric system is associated with the energy dissipation process in the dielectric system. The respective patterns of the frequency-dependent loss tangent (tanδ) of our un-doped and Gd-doped BT systems is shown in Fig. 7b. It can be observed that the loss tangent of those samples drops rapidly in the low-frequency range but slowly in the higher-frequency region. The decrease in loss tangent with increase in frequency can be explained in the light of diminution of polarization with increasing frequency. It is noticeable that, in the low-frequency region, the value of tanδ was quite high compared to its un-doped counterpart. However, in the high-frequency region, tanδ seems to be independent of doping.

Section3.Heading: Alternating-current conductivity and impedance formalism
Section3.Para:
Electrical conductivity is the measure of a specimen’s ability to allow free flow of charges. The lectrical nature of metals can be easily handled but that of dielectrics may be complicated owing to varying degrees of immobile charges, lattice disorder, dipolar response etc. In its most generic form, the complex electrical conductivity of a dielectric system can be stated as
9
$$ \sigma^* = \sigma_{1} +\ \mathrm{i} \sigma_{2}, $$ where σ 1 and σ 2 are real and imaginary parts. Again, the real part can be expressed as the sum total of frequency-independent (dc conductivity) and frequency-dependent (ac conductivity) components:
10
$$ \begin{aligned}[b] \sigma_{1} &= \sigma_{\mathrm{dc}} + \sigma_{\mathrm{ac}} \\ &= \sigma_{\mathrm{dc}} + K \omega^{s}. \end{aligned} $$ Here, s is a frequency exponent and s<1. This expression is a consequence of universal dielectric response theory, where K is a temperature-dependent parameter and the exponent s is a characteristic parameter which represents many-body interactions of the electrons, free charges and impurities [38]. The exponent generally varies between 0 and 1 and, for the ideal Debye type, it is exactly equal to unity. At a finite temperature, as σ dc realizes a much smaller magnitude, it is reasonable to consider the total conductivity as due only to the ac component. The frequency-dependent variation of the electrical conductivity (σ) of our nano-BT systems, for different Gd-doping concentrations, is shown in Fig. 8a. The conductivity is generally independent of frequency up to 10 kHz, but experiences a steep rising trend afterwards, following a σ ac∼ω
s dependency. In the low-frequency range, random diffusion of charge carriers via hopping gives rise to a nearly frequency independent conductivity. The high-frequency conductivity dispersion is attributed to the ac conductivity, whereas the nearly frequency independent regime may be associated with the dc conductivity (σ dc) of the system. Furthermore, the conductivity showed a higher magnitude with an increased doping level in the low-frequency zone (say, 0.3 to 10 kHz). The higher values of conductivity at higher frequencies is due to the reduction of space-charge polarization and active participation of oxygen vacancies induced by a trivalent rare-earth acceptor dopant (in the present case, Gd3+), which occupies the Ti4+ sites of the BT lattice [39]. Nevertheless, the conductivity trend of the 7 % Gd-doped BT sample was not significant, unlike other doped cases. The formation of a substantially larger number of oxygen vacancies, that leads to partial ordering of oxygen vacancies, would make them less mobile and that is why a conductivity drop was noticeable [40]. It is now apparent that the role of Gd doping is significant especially in the high-frequency range. Using the logarithm form of Eq. (10), we find that
11
$$ s = \frac{\mathrm{d} (\log \sigma_{\mathrm{ac}})}{\mathrm{d} (\log \omega )}. $$ If we plot logσ ac vs. logω (or, log f as ω=2πf), then the slope of the trace will provide the value of s. The representative plots are illustrated in Fig. 8b. Since the low-frequency regime may contain a dc component, we have calculated the s values from the linear part of the experimental data between 10 kHz and 1 MHz. The frequency exponent was estimated as s=0.65, 0.75, 0.9 and 0.69 for the 0, 1, 3 and 7 % Gd-doping cases. Indeed, the introduction of Gd has a role in improving the ac conductivity, especially in the high-frequency regime. But, a higher doping concentration may not add value to the system. In both 1 and 3 % Gd-doped BT systems, plentiful carriers would follow the applied field at a relatively lower frequency as for the un-doped and heavily doped (7 %) cases. A mild Gd doping, on the other hand, drives the system more toward ideal Debye-type behavior.
Fig. 8
The frequency-dependent conductivity of nano-BT systems with varying Gd doping level: (a) absolute and (b) log scales of σ

Generally, the correlated barrier hopping (CBH) model [41] is employed to estimate the barrier height (E b) of non-crystalline semiconductors. Based on the spin-pairing formalism, the model suggests hopping of electron pairs from a doubly occupied D + state to a nearly D − state over a barrier separating the two distinctly different states. In the pair-approximation model, a major contribution to the ac conductivity arises from the hopping within the pairs of sites for which ωτ=1 [41]. In the absence of any one state, E b represents the energy associated in taking two electrons to the conduction band. From the expression of the ac conductivity (Eqs. (9) and (11)), and in the light of the CBH model [41], the exponent can be directly correlated to the barrier height as per the following relation:
12
$$ s = \frac{\mathrm{d} (\ln \sigma_{\mathrm{ac}})}{\mathrm{d} (\ln \omega )} \approx 1 - \frac{6 k_{\beta} T}{E_{\mathrm{b}}}. $$ Since s has varied with Gd doping, we expect a variation in E b. The obtained values of optical band gap, s and E b are highlighted in Table 2.
Table 2

Barrier height (E b) (eV)

The addition of metal ion impurities was found to have a diminishing D + state as compared to the D − one. The resulting change in the conduction mechanism appears to occur via two processes, namely single-polaron hopping between randomly distributed defect sites and bipolaron hopping between non-randomly distributed defect sites. At a lower temperature, the calculation based on the CBH model for the bipolaron-hopping contribution agrees quite well with the experimental data points. The single-polaron-hopping process, however, is the dominant contributor of σ′(ω) only at higher temperatures [42].

Based on graphical representation, the fundamental impedance (Z′) formalism offers an important scope to the electrical conduction process of carriers in response to frequency. Essentially, the resistive response due to bulk (intra-grain) and grain boundary (inter-grain) effects can be assessed by plotting the imaginary component (Z″) on the y-axis and the real part (Z′) on the x-axis, giving a Cole–Cole plot [43]. It helps in eliminating stray frequency effects and in determining inter-particle interactions like grain, grain-boundary effects etc. [44]. Ideally, the intercept of the semicircular arc on the x-axis is an estimate of the bulk resistance (R g) of the material and indicates the departure from the ideal Debye behavior. The polycrystalline material generally exhibits two semicircles, one for intra-grain impedance (high-frequency region) and the other for inter-grain or grain-boundary impedance (moderate-frequency region) along with a spike for the electrode process in the low-frequency regime [45]. In the present case, only one incomplete semicircle was observed along with a spike depicting that the grain-boundary impedance is dominating over the bulk type (Fig. 9a). This illustrates the existence of an electroactive region equivalent to a device circuit consisting of a parallel resistance (grain boundary resistance, R gb) and capacitance (grain-boundary capacitance, C gb) network in series with a series resistance R g, due to the grain resistance. The intercepts of the arc at high-frequency ends gives the bulk resistance. It can also be seen from the figure that the nature of the Cole–Cole plot is highly dependent on Gd doping. With increasing doping concentration, the trace bends more toward the real axis and becomes almost semicircular indicating increase in conductivity. The semicircles also showed (on extrapolating) a trend of intersecting the Z′ axis, with the intersection point giving the value of the resistance R dc (=R gb) due to the dc value of the frequency (i.e. at f=0). The respective magnitudes for 1, 3 and 7 % Gd-doped BT systems were found to be 1.65, 1.35 and 1.2 MΩ. Moreover, the concerned frequency maxima, for un-doped and doped nano-BT specimens and corresponding to the Cole–Cole plots, were found as 4.018, 3.177, 2.543 and 5.485 kHz.
Fig. 9
(a) Cole–Cole plot (Z″ vs. Z′ plot) and (b) frequency-dependent nature of Z″ of un-doped and Gd-doped nano-BT systems

The nature of the imaginary part of the impedance (Z″) as a function of frequency is presented in Fig. 9b. The magnitude of Z″ was found to decrease with increasing ac frequency, indicating an enhanced carrier conduction process. The plots also ensure the existence of relaxed charged entities in the systems under study. Moreover, an asymmetric broadening of the peak suggests the involvement of typical conduction events with a spread of different relaxation time scales. In a relaxing system, one can determine the most probable relaxation time (τ) from the positions of the peaks in the Z″ vs. log f plot as they are related as τ=1/ω=1/2πf. Referring to Fig. 9b, it can be observed that the peak maxima suffer a shifting toward the low-frequency side with increasing doping concentration. Consequently, the relaxation time gets enhanced with Gd-doping level. The peak position attained an optimum value of shifting for the 1 % Gd-doped BT system and gradually moves toward the higher-frequency side thereafter. The relaxation frequency has varied with increasing Gd-doping concentration, with the average relaxation times estimated as 39.9, 50.3, 28.3 and 44.9 μs for un-doped and 1, 3 and 7 % Gd-doped systems, respectively. Thus, it is now apparent that a mild Gd doping into the BT host manifests dielectric properties significantly with an improved value in exponent, barrier height and relaxation time. Furthermore, though 7 % of Gd doping is permissible with unperturbed structural evolution, an improved electrical conduction feature was realized at a relatively lower doping level.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
To conclude, we have demonstrated structural, optical and dielectric relaxation features of the Gd-doped BT nanostructured systems. From XRD and TEM studies, we found that the BT system is pseudo-cubic in nature and has a tetragonality value close to unity. With Gd doping, the optical band gap was found to be reduced substantially but the band tailing parameter (Urbach energy) showed an increasing trend. Both dielectric constant as well as loss tangent followed a declining trend with increase in applied frequency, but to a varying extent. The conductivity was found to be independent of frequency up to 10 kHz, but experienced an increasing trend afterwards, following a σ ac∼ω
s dependency. The enhancement of the conductivity feature at a higher frequency has been demonstrated in the light of the CBH model. When the exponent s approaches unity, as for the low-Gd-doping case, it inadvertently signified close to ideal Debye behavior. In the impedance formalism where a semicircular nature of the Cole–Cole plots was witnessed, the chief contributor was revealed as the grain boundary resistance (R gb) with calculated values as 1.65, 1.35 and 1.2 MΩ for 1, 3 and 7 % of Gd-doping cases. Finally, the relaxation events were found to be manifested with Gd doping. More work in the direction of carrier lifetime measurement, evaluation of paramagnetic centers and radiative emission response is in progress.
